{{Italic title}} {{Infobox film | name = Oro | image = OroPoster.jpg | alt = | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[Alvin Yapan]] | producer = Mark Shandii Bacolod | writer = Alvin Yapan | based on = | starring = {{Plainlist| * [[Irma Adlawan]] * [[Mercedes Cabral]] * [[Joem Bascon]] }} | music = Harold Andre Cruz Santos
Hiroko Nagai | cinematography = Ronald Rebutica | editing = Benjamin Tolentino | studio = Feliz Film Productions | distributor = [[Solar Entertainment Corporation|Solar Pictures]]{{cite news|title=(UPDATED) MMFF Execom's Wilson Tieng to distribute Sunday Beauty Queen, Oro, and Saving Sally|url=http://www.pep.ph/news/65463/mmff-execoms-wilson-tieng-to-distributeem-sunday-beauty-queenem-emoroem-and-emsaving-sallyem|accessdate=3 April 2017|work=PEP.ph|date=3 December 2016}} | released = {{Film date|2016|12|25}} | runtime = 110 minutes | country = [[Philippines]] | language = [[Filipino language|Filipino]] | budget = | gross = }} '''''Oro''''' ({{literal translation|Gold}}) is a 2016 [[Philippines|Filipino]] film written and directed by [[Alvin Yapan]], starring [[Irma Adlawan]], [[Mercedes Cabral]], and [[Joem Bascon]].{{cite news|title=8 MMFF 2016 entries revealed|url=http://www.rappler.com/entertainment/news/152823-mmff-2016-entries-full-list|accessdate=22 November 2016|work=Rappler|date=18 November 2016}} The film, which was produced by Feliz Film Productions and distributed by Solar Pictures,{{cite news|last1=Dimaculangan|first1=Jocelyn|title=MMFF 2016 boldly touted to be "renaissance in Philippine cinema"|url=http://www.pep.ph/guide/mmff/25075/mmff-2016-predicted-to-be-renaissance-in-philippine-cinema?ref=ob_related|accessdate=22 November 2016|work=Philippine Entertainment Portal|publisher=Philippine Entertainment Portal Inc.|date=20 November 2016}} was an official entry to the [[2016 Metro Manila Film Festival]].{{cite web|title=Here are the films competing in MMFF 2016|url=http://news.abs-cbn.com/entertainment/11/18/16/here-are-the-films-competing-in-mmff-2016|website=ABS-CBN News|accessdate=22 November 2016|date=18 November 2016}} The film was based on the 2014 murder of four miners in Sitio Lahuy, Barangay Gata, [[Caramoan]], [[Camarines Sur]] by armed members of Sagip Kalikasan Task Force, an environmental group formed in 2004 by former Camarines Sur governor [[Luis Villafuerte]]. During its screening in the 2016 Metro Manila Film Festival, the film was criticized for scenes of animal cruelty, wherein a dog was shown beaten to death, disemboweled, cooked and eaten by the actors. An investigation conducted by the festival's executive committee found that a dog was indeed killed and disemboweled during filming but wasn't eaten by the actors. The executive committee ordered the producers to edit out the scenes of animal cruelty from the film. It also ordered the film's withdrawal from movie theaters and banned the film's director and producers from participating in the festival for one year. The animal welfare group [[Philippine Animal Welfare Society]] (PAWS) also filed a lawsuit against the film director and production company for violating the Philippine Animal Welfare Law. ==Synopsis== A secluded community dependent on mining is disrupted by an armed group who claims to be a representative of the government which causes a change in the traditional way of life of the community's residents. The community is led by a Barangay chairperson ([[Irma Adlawan]]) who decides to deal with the armed group exploiting their simple and previously undisturbed community. ==Cast== {{columns-list|colwidth=30em| * [[Irma Adlawan]] as Kapitana * [[Joem Bascon]] as Elmer * [[Mercedes Cabral]] as Linda * [[Nora Aunor]] as old Kapitana * Sandino Martin as Cesar * [[Sue Prado]] as Letty Razon * Biboy Ramirez as Lando * Cedrick Juan as Bong * Timothy Castillo as Boy }} ==Production== ===Development and writing=== ''Oro'' is largely based on a true story on killings which took place in 2014. The real life event now dubbed as the "Gata Four Massacre" involved the killing of four miners in Barangay Gata, [[Caramoan]], [[Camarines Sur]]. In a March 2016 ''Bicol Today'' report, the alleged perpetrators were described as "enjoying freedom as employees of the Sagip Kalikasan Task Force" (SKTF). Alvin Yapan, the film's writer and director stated that significant parts of the event were fictionalized as a move of sensitivity to the case of the families of the victims.{{cite news|last1=Villano|first1=Alex|title=MMFF 2016: Based on true events, 'Oro' brings tough issues to light|url=http://www.rappler.com/entertainment/movies/156235-oro-movie-irma-adlawan-joem-bascon-mercedes-cabral-facts|accessdate=2 January 2017|work=Rappler|date=30 December 2016|language=English, Filipino}} The SKTF for example, was fictionalized as the Patrol Kalikasan.{{cite news|last1=Tantiangco|first1=Aya|title=PAWS seeks probe on depiction of animal cruelty in ‘Oro’|url=http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/594249/lifestyle/paws-seeks-probe-on-depiction-of-animal-cruelty-in-oro|accessdate=3 January 2017|work=GMA News|date=31 December 2016}} Camarines Sur Representative and ''Oro'' producer Wimpy Fuentebella approached Yapan to direct ''Oro''. Yapan initially refused saying that he doesn't want to be involved in politics but later accepted the project after Fuentebella approached him again at the [[Ateneo de Manila University]] where Yapan teaches. Fuentebella appealed to Yapan to direct the film to advance an advocacy as an Atenean and Bicolano. Yapan asked for full creative control over the production of ''Oro'' and was assured that the film isn't a propaganda or a smear campaign. ===Filming=== The film was shot in the Sitio Lahuy, Barangay Gata, Caramoan, Camarines Sur, where the 2014 killings took place. Both residents and non-residents participated as extras in the making of the film. Some of the extras were later found out by Yapan to be relatives of the victims and the director expressed reluctance saying that their participation may worsen their trauma from the killings. The victims' relatives insisted to be part of the film saying to the production team that it's their story and the film is them. Yapan described the experience of the victims' relatives working with the film as seemingly therapeutic adding that they "kept silent about the entire thing and now people are actually interested in the material so this is their chance to speak. And their way of speaking is to act a particular thing that they actually experienced" ==Reception== ===Box office=== ''Oro'' is among the four least performing films in terms of box office sales during the opening day of the [[2016 Metro Manila Film Festival]] on 25 December 2016.{{cite news|title=Which film topped the 2016 MMFF box office?|url=http://www.businessmirror.com.ph/which-film-topped-the-2016-mmff-box-office/|accessdate=3 January 2017|work=BusinessMirror|date=27 December 2016}} After reports of animal cruelty in the film came out, the festival's executive ordered the movie withdrawn from movie theaters beginning 4 January 2017. ===Critical response=== Notwithstanding scenes of animal cruelty in the film, the film received positive reviews from several movie critics. Oggs Cruz of [[Rappler]] called the film a "power discourse". He writes: "The film, however, is not just about injustice, which is quite an obvious concept. It is about the fickle nature of justice, of the impossibility of organized society to pinpoint with exactitude what equates as just in a world of multiple advocacies and perspectives. This is what makes the film overwhelmingly compelling."{{cite web |url=http://www.rappler.com/entertainment/movies/156857-oro-movie-review-irma-adlawan-joem-bascon |title='Oro' Review: Powerful discourse |author=Cruz, Oggs |date=28 December 2016 |publisher=''[[Rappler]]'' |accessdate=7 January 2017}} Don Jaucian, writing for [[CNN Philippines]] said, "Yapan skillfully weaves the details of the town’s life through little stories of faith and redemption, stories that build up to a riveting portrait of greed, corruption, and helplessness."{{cite web |url=http://cnnphilippines.com/life/entertainment/film/2016/12/30/mmff-reviews-part-2.html |title=MMFF roundup, part 2: ‘Die Beautiful,’ ‘Oro,’ ‘Sunday Beauty Queen,’ and ‘Vince and Kath and James’ |author=Jaucian, Don |date=30 December 2016 |publisher=[[CNN Philippines]] |accessdate=7 January 2017}} Camille Anne Arcilla, writing for ''[[BusinessWorld]]'' said, "Heavy as it may seem for Christmas entertainment, but it leaves a mark to the audience, not just as a moviegoer, but also as a member of a society."{{cite web |url=http://www.bworldonline.com/content.php?section=Arts&Leisure&title=search-for-gold-human-nature&id=138291 |title=Search for gold, human nature |author=Arcilla, Camille Anne |date=28 December 2016 |publisher=''[[BusinessWorld]]'' |accessdate=7 January 2017}} Bubbles Salvador of the [[Philippine Entertainment Portal]] called the film "intelligent, relevant, real" and adds that Yapan brilliantly tackles the issues that need to be brought to light in a film that has the elements an ordinary moviegoer looks for: a tight storyline, characters one can relate to, and a lesson at the end.{{cite web |url=http://www.pep.ph/guide/mmff/25279/mmff-2016-review-emoro-ema-gripping-eye-opener-inspired-by-real-life-caramoan-massacre |title=Oro, a gripping eye-opener inspired by real-life Caramoan massacre |author=Salvador, Bubbles |date=24 December 2016 |publisher=PEP.ph |accessdate=7 January 2017}} ===Awards=== The film was nominated for 10 awards in the 2016 Metro Manila Film Festival. During the festival's awards night on 29 December 2016 held at the [[Kia Theater]] in [[Quezon City]], the film's lead actress, [[Irma Adlawan]] won the Best Actress award for her role as Kapitana. The film's cast also won Best Ensemble while the film received the Fernando Poe, Jr. Memorial Award for Excellence, which was later revoked after reports of animal cruelty in the film surfaced. {|class="wikitable" style="font-size: 95%;" !Award !Recipient !Result |- |- ||Best Picture |rowspan="1" | |{{Nominated}} |- |- ||Best Actor |rowspan="1" | [[Joem Bascon]] |{{Nominated}} |- |- ||Best Actress |rowspan="1" | [[Irma Adlawan]] |{{Won}} |- |- ||Best Supporting Actor |rowspan="1" | Cedrick Juan |{{Nominated}} |- |- ||Best Supporting Actress |rowspan="1" | [[Mercedes Cabral]] |{{Nominated}} |- |- ||Best Ensemble Cast |rowspan="1" | |{{Won}} |- |- ||Best Cinematography |rowspan="1" | Roland Rebutica |{{Nominated}} |- ||Best Sound Design |rowspan="1" | Harold Andre Cruz Santos and Hiroko Nagai |{{Nominated}} |- ||[[Fernando Poe Jr.]] Memorial Award{{cite web |url=http://www.rappler.com/entertainment/news/156705-winners-mmff-2016-awards-night-full-list-gabi-ng-parangal |title=FULL LIST: Winners, MMFF 2016 Gabi ng Parangal |date=29 December 2016 |publisher=''[[Rappler]]'' |accessdate=7 January 2017}} |rowspan="1" | |{{Won}} (Withdrawn) |- ||Best Original Theme Song |rowspan="1" | ''Nananaghoy ang Puso Ko'' by Tonton Hernandez |{{Nominated}} |} ==Criticism== ===Animal cruelty during filming=== The scene in the film which depicts members of Patrol Kalikasan taking a dog of a villager to later slaughter and cook it elicited controversy. Animal rights group [[Philippine Animal Welfare Society]] (PAWS) criticized the inclusion of the scene and alleged that the dog was actually killed in real life.{{cite news|title=MMFF ExeCom withdraws Fernando Poe Jr Memorial Award from 'Oro'|url=http://www.rappler.com/entertainment/news/157272-mmff-executive-committee-announces-withdrawal-fernando-poe-jr-memorial-award-oro|accessdate=3 January 2017|work=Rappler|date=3 January 2017}} PAWS called for an investigation regarding the certain scene saying that those involved are liable under Republic Act 8485 or the Animal Welfare Act. They pointed out that there was no permit application filed to the Bureau of Animal Industry and the Committee on Animal Welfare by either the filmmakers or the indigenous community. PAWS also added that if the dog slaughter was not deliberately filmed by the filmmakers, they said that the production team of ''Oro'' should have reported the incident instead of using the footage as part of their feature film. Yapan stated that neither he or a member of the film's cast were involved in the killing of the dog and that the production team only documented a "culture of violence" in a remote portion of the country. Following a closed-door meeting with the MMFF Executive Committee, the filmmakers and PAWS decided to censor or edit out the scene in question, as well as include an advisory warning viewers of graphic content, which they described as a "compromise". PAWS expressed disappointment in the decision, saying that the move "does not change the fact that a dog was killed" for the film describing the events in the scene as "a crime committed". The group also criticized the MMFF committee for not pulling out the film entirely alleging that they hide under a "technicality" in such that the production team of ''Oro'' was not directly involved in the killing of the dog. PAWS said that a "degree of ethics" dictates that the film makers should not have used the footage for their work.{{cite news|last1=Sallan|first1=Edwin|title=‘Oro’ director to edit out dog slaughter scene, PAWS vows legal action|url=http://www.interaksyon.com/entertainment/oro-director-to-edit-out-dog-slaughter-scene-paws-vows-legal-action/|accessdate=3 January 2017|work=InterAksyon.com|date=2 January 2017}} Yapan has expressed disappointment and noted that public attention regarding the film would be more directed to the dog slaughter scene rather than the case of the Gata 4 Massacre. On 3 January 2017, the MMFF Executive Committee revoked the Fernando Poe Jr Memorial Award from ''Oro'' after a consultation with the family of the late [[Fernando Poe Jr.]]. They said that "without making any judgment on the artistic merit of the film or cinematic depiction", the controversy regarding the alleged killing of a dog in the making of ''Oro'' "effectively casts a doubt on the movie's ability to exemplify the human and cultural values espoused by the late Fernando Poe, Jr."{{cite news|title=MMFF ExeCom withdraws Fernando Poe Jr Memorial Award from 'Oro'|url=http://www.rappler.com/entertainment/news/157272-mmff-executive-committee-announces-withdrawal-fernando-poe-jr-memorial-award-oro|accessdate=3 January 2017|work=Rappler|date=3 January 2017}} On 24 January 2017, Superstar [[Nora Aunor]] called the fillmakers behind the controversial movie "Oro" liars for denying that a dog was killed during the shooting of the film. Both Aunor and Yapan attended the hearing of the Senate committee on public information and mass media over different issues concerning the [[Metro Manila Film Festival]] (MMFF). Yapan said nobody from the crew killed a dog. Aunor, however, refuted Yapan's statement, saying it was stated in the script that one dog will be killed. She earlier said that two dogs will be killed but then clarified the matter later on during the hearing. The actress also complained of not receiving a formal notice from the director nor the producer that she will no longer continue on with the project, despite already having attended a story conference. Senator [[Grace Poe]], chair of the Senate panel conducting the hearing, gave Yapan an opportunity to apologize over the incident.{{cite news|last1=Alvarez|first1=Katrina Charmaine|title=Nora Aunor calls Oro filmmakers liars for denying killing of dog for movie|url=http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/596877/showbiz/nora-aunor-calls-oro-filmmakers-liars-for-denying-killing-of-dog-for-movie|accessdate=24 January 2017|work=GMANetwork.com|date=24 January 2017}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} [[Category:Philippine films]] [[Category:Philippine New Wave]] [[Category:Mining in film]] [[Category:Films shot in Camarines Sur]] [[Category:Obscenity controversies in film]] [[Category:Animal cruelty incidents]] [[Category:Films Directed by Vim Yapan]]

A '''paper street''' is a [[road]] or [[street]] that appears on maps but does not exist in reality.<ref>Sanderson, Paul G.,[https://www.nhmunicipal.org/TownAndCity/Article/56 "Paper Streets: The Gap Between Dedication and Acceptance"], [[New Hampshire]] local government center, United States, 04-2007. Retrieved 10-13-2008.</ref> Paper streets generally occur when [[Urban planning|city planners]] or [[Subdivision (land)|subdivision]] developers lay out and dedicate streets that are never built.<ref>http://www.nhbar.org/publications/archives/display-journal-issue.asp?id=203</ref><ref>http://www.njslom.org/mag1107_article_pg38.html</ref> Commercial street maps based only on official subdivision and land records may show these streets, which are legally public [[rights of way]] though usually undriveable.
Paper streets (and, by extension, '''paper towns''') may be deliberately included in published maps as [[trap street]]s, forming a [[fictitious entry#Maps|copyright trap]].
A [[wordplay|play]] on the phrase is found in [[Chuck Palahniuk]]'s novel ''[[Fight Club (novel)|Fight Club]]'', as well as [[Fight Club (film)|the film based on that book]], where the protagonist lives in a house on "Paper street".
Paper towns play a large role in [[John Green (author)|John Green]]'s novel ''[[Paper Towns]]''.

'''Passion Conferences''' (also referred to as '''Passion''' and '''the 268 Generation''', originally named '''Choice Ministries''') is a [[Christian]] organization founded by [[Louie Giglio]] in 1997. The organization is known for their annual gatherings of young adults between the ages of 18–25, more specifically college students. The organization is also responsible for [[sixstepsrecords]], Passion Music, and the [[megachurch]] Passion City Church.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.christianitytoday.com/ct/2009/february/28.17.html|title=Q&A: Louie Giglio|author=Interview Sarah Eekhoff Zylstra|work=''ChristianityToday.com''|accessdate=January 1, 2015}}</ref> The first conference was Passion '97, held in [[Austin, Texas|Austin]], Texas. Today, the headquarters are in [[Roswell, Georgia|Roswell]], a suburb of [[Atlanta]], Georgia.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sbcbaptistpress.org/bpnews.asp?ID=24698|title=Baptist Press – Passion '07 kicks off with 21,000 adults in Atlanta – News with a Christian Perspective|website=''sbcbaptistpress.org''|accessdate=November 11, 2017|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070510225709/http://www.sbcbaptistpress.org/bpnews.asp?ID=24698|archivedate=May 10, 2007}}</ref><ref>Georgia Secretary of State office, control number 10018357</ref> According to the organization, their purpose is to unite college students for a "spiritual awakening in this generation". The foundation of their purpose can be found in [[Isaiah 26|Isaiah 26:8]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.268generation.com|title=Passion Conferences|accessdate=January 1, 2015}}</ref>
Since its start in 1997, Passion Conferences has operated as a national conference. Passion Conferences launched their first of many global tours in 2008 that visited 17 different countries,<ref>{{cite web|author=Tweet Email |url=http://www.christiantoday.co.uk/article/passion.conferences.to.go.international.in.2008/9005.htm |title=Passion Conferences to Go International in 2008 | Christian News on Christian Today |publisher=Christiantoday.co.uk |date=January 9, 2007 |accessdate=January 9, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.charismanews.com/us/36978-college-students-worship-pray-serve-at-passion-2010-event|title=College Students Worship, Pray, Serve at Passion 2010 Event|last=Gaines|first=Adrienne S.|work=Charisma News|access-date=November 19, 2018}}</ref> kicking off in [[Kiev]], Ukraine and finishing in [[Sydney]], Australia. Since then, Passion Conferences have continued to host gatherings in the United States and all over the world.
==History==
=== 1985–1997: Early years === In 1985, Louie and Shelley Giglio founded Choice Ministries at Baylor University in Waco, TX.<ref name="cbn.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.cbn.com/700club/guests/bios/louiegiglio092409.aspx|title=Louie Giglio: The Heart Behind the Passion|accessdate=January 1, 2015}}</ref> Choice Ministries began as a campus-based student ministry and after 10 years of ministry at Baylor, Louie and Shelley moved to Atlanta, GA. In 1997, Giglio founded Passion Conferences in Atlanta under the banner of Choice Ministries to see a spiritual awakening among college students all across the United States and the world.
=== 1997–2007: National success === The first conference took place in Austin, TX where thousands of college aged students came together during January 1–4, 1997.<ref name="cbn.com" /> Passion have hosted five more national gatherings in the next decade (1998, 1999, 2005, 2006, 2007), which involved more than 70,000 college students in total.<ref name="cbn.com" /> During this decade, thousands of additional college students connected with Passion through one of several other gatherings, including the OneDay Gatherings in 2000 and 2003<ref name="christianpost.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.christianpost.com/news/passion-conferences-oneday-03-4386/|title=Passion Conferences 'OneDay 03'|work=The Christian Post|accessdate=January 1, 2015}}</ref> and the Passion Experience Tour.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.christianpost.com/news/the-2003-passion-experience-tour-dates-4465/|title=The 2003 Passion Experience Tour Dates|website=The Christian Post|dead-url=|access-date=November 19, 2018}}</ref> Passion also became known for its worship albums over this decade, which featured many prominent contemporary Christian artists like [[Matt Redman]], [[Chris Tomlin]], and [[Crowder (musician)|David Crowder]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/one-day-live-mw0000104728|title=One Day Live - Passion {{!}} Songs, Reviews, Credits {{!}} AllMusic|publisher=AllMusic|dead-url=|access-date=November 19, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/our-love-is-loud-mw0000216593|title=Our Love Is Loud - Passion {{!}} Songs, Reviews, Credits {{!}} AllMusic|publisher=AllMusic|access-date=November 19, 2018}}</ref>
=== 2008–present: Passion City Church and world tours === In 2008, Giglio, with the help of Chris Tomlin, founded [[megachurch]] Passion City Church, a branch of Passion Conferences, in Atlanta, GA.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://john.do/chris-tomlin-leaving-austin-stone/|title=Chris Tomlin leaving Austin Stone!!! – john saddington|date=May 11, 2008|work=john saddington|access-date=November 19, 2018}}</ref> Passion City Church would later expand to [[Cumberland, Georgia|Cumberland]], Georgia<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.ajc.com/news/local/passion-city-church-approved-for-cumberland-expansion/MkwsuA84kFwKlSmqoSQOrL/|title=Passion City Church approved for Cumberland expansion|work=ajc|access-date=November 19, 2018}}</ref> and [[Washington, D.C.]] in 2017.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://passioncitychurch.com/dc/|title=D.C. |work=Passion City Church|access-date=November 19, 2018}}</ref> In the same year, Passion Conferences embarked on their first world tour, reaching out to 17 different cities in all 6 continents.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.christianpost.com/news/over-20000-students-attend-passion-2014-conference-in-atlanta-112930/|title=Over 20,000 Students Attend Passion 2014 Conference in Atlanta|website=The Christian Post|access-date=November 19, 2018}}</ref> Passion has continued to launch world tours and regular tours throughout the years, including Passion NYC Subway Series,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.christianpost.com/news/passion-reaches-out-to-nyc-students-through-subway-series-5285|title=Passion Reaches Out To NYC Students Through Subway Series|website=The Christian Post|dead-url=|access-date=November 19, 2018}}</ref> Regionals '07–'08, Passion 2010 University Tour, Passion 2012 University Tour, A Night of Worship with Passion Tour, Passion: Let the Future Begin Tour, and Passion: Take It All Tour. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.themcollective.com/press-archive/2014/8/19/kristian-stanfill-to-lead-26-city-passion-take-it-all-tour-kicking-off-september-10|title=Kristian Stanfill to Lead 26-City "Passion: Take It All" Tour, Kicking Off September 10|work=the media collective|accessdate=January 1, 2015}}</ref> Passion's regular conferences have also become annually held. The Passion conference in 2016 was simultaneously held in three arenas in two cities: [[Toyota Center]] in Houston, Texas; [[Infinite Energy Arena]] in Atlanta, Georgia; and [[Philips Arena]] in Atlanta, Georgia. Through live streaming capabilities, students were able to see the various speakers and musicians from each of the three venues throughout the 3-day event.<ref>{{Cite web | url = http://www.theblaze.com/stories/2016/01/05/this-is-what-it-looks-like-when-40000-young-people-pack-three-arenas-to-worship-jesus-and-heres-the-stunning-thing-they-accomplished/ |title=40,000 Christian College Students Flood Three Arenas for Massive 'Passion' Event – and Here's the Remarkable Thing They Accomplished |website= The Blaze | access-date = February 25, 2016}}</ref>
In 2017, Passion held their annual collegiate event in Atlanta, Georgia's Georgia Dome, former home of the Atlanta Falcons before renovations.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ajc.com/lifestyles/passion-2017-atlanta-faith-filled-event-reaches-out-millennials/W60iebk3StU4YFNhYz4eiI/|title=Passion 2017: Atlanta faith-filled event reaches out to millennials|first=Shelia|last=Poole|website=ajc|accessdate=November 11, 2017}}</ref> That year, Passion encouraged participants to sponsored more than 7,000 a children from [[Compassion International]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.christianitytoday.com/news/2017/january/passion-conference-students-child-sponsorship-compassion.html/|title=Passion Students Sponsor Every Compassion Child in Four Countries|website=''christianitytoday.com''|accessdate=November 11, 2017}}</ref> The conference also saw the debut of sixsteprecords latest artist [[Jimi Cravity]]<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://echo.snu.edu/passion2017/|title=Passion 2017 Overview|date=January 24, 2017|work=The Echo|access-date=November 19, 2018}}</ref> and the guest appearance of country music singer [[Carrie Underwood]], which incited considerable Christian backlash.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.ajc.com/blog/music/carrie-underwood-incites-christian-backlash-after-passion-2017-performance/0eYSCKaXc37y8LkgT9l34L/|title=Carrie Underwood incites Christian backlash after Passion 2017 performance|work=ajc|access-date=November 19, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/1775308/carrie-underwood-crashes-passion/|title=Carrie Underwood Crashes Passion|work=CMT News|access-date=November 19, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://tasteofcountry.com/carrie-underwoods-passion-2017-performance-criticism-gay-marriage/|title=Carrie Underwood's Appearance at Passion 2017 Attacked|website=Taste of Country|dead-url=|access-date=November 19, 2018}}</ref>
== Music == {{Infobox musical artist | name = Passion | background = group_or_band | alias = Passion Music | origin = [[Atlanta]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|GA]], United States | genre = {{hlist|[[Contemporary Christian]]|[[Contemporary worship music|Praise & Worship]]}} | years_active = {{start date|1997}}–present | label = {{hlist|[[sixsteps]]records|[[Capitol CMG]]|[[Sparrow Records]]}} | current_members = * [[Chris Tomlin]] * [[Charlie Hall (musician)|Charlie Hall]] * [[David Crowder|Crowder]] * [[Kristian Stanfill]] * [[Christy Nockels]] * [[Matt Redman]] * Melodie Malone * [[Brett Younker]] * [[Jimi Cravity]] }} Passion Conferences have released 28 albums over the span of 2 decades under the name Passion. Most of the Passion albums are live albums, recorded during performances in conferences or tours. Passion Conferences also owns sixstepsrecords, a record label that includes [[Crowder (musician)|Crowder]] and Passion.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://sixstepsrecords.com/discography/|title=Discography|date=November 6, 2014|work=sixstepsrecords|access-date=November 19, 2018}}</ref>
Passion's first record, Our Soul's Desire, was released in 1997 under [[Star Song Communications|Star Song Records]]. After Star Song artists transferred to [[Sparrow Records]],<ref name="BB_12-98">{{cite journal|last=Price|first=Deborah Evans|date=December 5, 1998|title=EMI's StarSong Shifts To Imprint Status|journal=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|page=5}}</ref> Passion released two more live albums, including 1999's ''[[Passion: Better Is One Day|Better Is One Day]]'', which saw Passion charting on the Billboard [[Christian Albums|Christian Albums chart]] for the first time.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://www.billboard.com/music/passion/chart-history/christian-albums|title=Passion Chart History|work=Billboard|access-date=November 19, 2018}}</ref> In 2000, Passion Conferences founded sixstepsrecords as a division of Passion Conferences.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.themcollective.com/passion/|title=Passion|website=the media collective|dead-url=|access-date=November 19, 2018}}</ref> As partners of Sparrow Records, a division of [[Capitol Christian Music Group|Capitol CMG]], sixstepsrecords has many prominent contemporary Christian musicians under their label.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.capitolchristianmusicgroup.com/about/about-ccmg.aspx|title=Capitol Christian Music Group|website=''capitolchristianmusicgroup.com''|dead-url=|access-date=November 19, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://christianmusicarchive.com/label/sixstepsrecords|title=sixstepsrecords {{!}} Christian Music Archive|website=''christianmusicarchive.com''|dead-url=|access-date=November 19, 2018}}</ref> Their first album on the newwly created label, ''[[Passion: The Road to One Day|The Road to One Day]]'', became the first Passion album to chart on the [[Billboard 200]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.billboard.com/music/passion/chart-history/billboard-200|title=Passion Chart History|work=Billboard|access-date=November 19, 2018}}</ref>
Since the creation of sixstepsrecords, Passion has released more than twenty more live albums and two studio albums, nine of which have consecutively charted at No. 1 on the Billboard Christian Albums chart.<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.jesusfreakhideout.com/artists/PassionBand.asp|title=Passion Band Discography, Passion Conference, Passion Artist Database, Lyrics {{!}} Jesusfreakhideout.com|website=www.jesusfreakhideout.com|dead-url=|access-date=November 19, 2018}}</ref> The lead single off of 2012's live album ''[[Passion: White Flag|White Flag]]'', "[[One Thing Remains (Passion song)|One Thing Remains]]", became Passion's first No. 1 song on the Billboard Christian Songs chart.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.billboard.com/music/passion/chart-history/christian-songs|title=Passion Chart History|work=Billboard|access-date=November 19, 2018}}</ref> Passion's ''[[Passion: Let the Future Begin|Let The Future Begin]]'' (2013) and ''[[Passion: Take It All|Take It All]]'' (2014) both peaked at No. 4 on the Billboard 200, making them Passion's highest charting albums.<ref name=":0" /> == Conferences == Passion's annual conferences attract around 50,000 participants. Every year, the conference invites prominent Christian speakers and musical artists.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.wvnews.com/theet/news/passion-conferences-helping-christian-youths-spread-the-gospel/article_49a3d2ea-9ab2-51ab-9ebf-0b20ef1bde08.html|title=Passion Conferences: Helping Christian youths spread the gospel|last=WRITER|first=Charles Young STAFF|work=WV News|access-date=November 19, 2018}}</ref>
=== Speakers === Pastor [[Louie Giglio]], founder of Passion, often speaks during the conferences. [[John Piper (theologian)|John Piper]] is also a frequent speaker at Passion Conferences. news|url=https://www.christianitytoday.com/news/2018/may/tim-keller-john-piper-andy-stanley-most-effective-preachers.html|title=Tim Keller, John Piper, and Andy Stanley Among the 12 ‘Most Effective’ === Artists === [[File:Passion São Paulo - Chris Tomlin.jpg|thumb|[[Chris Tomlin]] performing at the May 23–24, 2008 Passion Conference in [[São Paulo]], Brazil.]] [[Sixstepsrecords]] artists form the core group of artists performing at the Passion Gatherings, including [[Chris Tomlin]], [[David Crowder]], [[Charlie Hall (musician)|Charlie Hall]], [[Matt Redman]], [[Christy Nockels]], [[Kristian Stanfill]], Melodie Malone, [[Brett Younker]], and [[Jimi Cravity]].
Other artists that have performed at Passion Gatherings include [[Lecrae]], [[Hillsong United]], [[Jesus Culture]], [[Kari Jobe]], [[Tenth Avenue North]], [[Shane and Shane]], [[SonicFlood]], [[Gungor]], [[Rend Collective]], and Sean Curran of [[Bellarive]].
=== Door holders === The men and women who volunteer at the conferences are called door holders.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://268generation.com/passion2015/door-holders/|title=Door Holders |work=Passion 2015|accessdate=January 1, 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141231075653/http://268generation.com/passion2015/door-holders/|archivedate=December 31, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.wvnews.com/theet/news/passion-conferences-helping-christian-youths-spread-the-gospel/article_49a3d2ea-9ab2-51ab-9ebf-0b20ef1bde08.html|title=Passion Conferences: Helping Christian youths spread the gospel|last=WRITER|first=Charles Young STAFF|work=WV News|access-date=November 19, 2018}}</ref> They serve on different teams such as community groups, logistics and registration<ref>{{cite web|url=http://268generation.com/passion2015/door-holder-teams/|title=Door Holder Teams|work=Passion 2015|accessdate=January 1, 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141231080736/http://268generation.com/passion2015/door-holder-teams/|archivedate=December 31, 2014}}</ref> and are considered to be at the core of the gatherings. They travel from all over the nation to serve at these gatherings. At various times throughout the year Passion City Church has special events for Door Holders.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://passioncitychurch.com/usconference/|title=US Conference – Passion City Church|website=''passioncitychurch.com''|access-date=April 4, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.christianpost.com/news/55000-pack-georgia-dome-for-passion-2017-sponsor-over-7000-children-172670/|title=55,000 Pack Georgia Dome for Passion 2017, Sponsor Over 7,000 Children|website=The Christian Post|dead-url=|access-date=November 19, 2018}}</ref>
== Charitable contributions ==
In 2011, Passion started the Do Something Now fundraising campaign,<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://religion.blogs.cnn.com/2011/01/11/college-kids-feeling-passion-for-conference/|title=College kids feeling passion for conference|access-date=November 19, 2018}}</ref> later renamed 72DaysForFreedom. The fundraising campaign encourages participants in Passion's annual conferences to donate to different charitable organizations. In the Passion 2011 conference, over 22,000 students raised over $1.1 million towards multiple causes.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.christianpost.com/news/passion-2011-brings-in-record-high-11-million-48368/|title=Passion 2011 Brings in Record High $1.1 Million|work=The Christian Post}}</ref> In the 2012 conference, students raised $3.3 million to fund seven different organizations battle [[sex trafficking]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thecnnfreedomproject.blogs.cnn.com/2012/01/05/college-kids-vow-to-end-slavery/|title=College kids vow to end slavery}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cardinalandcream.info/2012/passion-conference-raises-more-than-3m-for-its-campaign-to-end-human-trafficking/|title=Passion conference raises more than $3M for its campaign to end human trafficking|date=February 22, 2012|work=Cardinal & Cream|access-date=November 19, 2018}}</ref>. Passion 2013 saw the launch of the End It Movement, an anti-human trafficking fundraising campaign. Attendees gave over $3.6 million towards various causes at this conference.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.christianpost.com/news/passion-2013-donates-over-3-million-to-fight-human-trafficking-88101/|title=Passion 2013 Donates Over $3 Million to Fight Human Trafficking|work=The Christian Post}}</ref>
At the 2015 Atlanta conference, attendees collected items to donate to Atlanta's [[City of Refuge (Atlanta)|City of Refuge]] homeless ministry.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.11alive.com/article/news/local/downtown/passion-conference-returns-to-philips-arena/286047433|title=Passion Conference returns to Philips Arena|publisher=WXIA|access-date=November 19, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.crew1.com/passion-conference-2015/|title=Passion Conference {{!}} Crew One|website=www.crew1.com|dead-url=|access-date=November 19, 2018}}</ref> In 2016, participants raised more than $800,000 towards ''Project Haraka'' حركة, a partnership with [[World Vision United States|World Vision USA]] to fund the building of a health facility in Syria.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.hallels.com/articles/14484/20160107/passion-conference-has-raised-811-813-39-for-project-haraka.htm|title=Passion Conference Has Raised $811,813.39 for Project Haraka|last=Hallels|website=''hallels.com''|dead-url=|access-date=November 19, 2018}}</ref> This building is intended to serve as the first newborn [[Intensive care unit|ICU]] in [[Syrian opposition|opposition-controlled Syria]].<ref>{{Cite web | url = http://www.thechristianbeat.org/index.php/news/1439-passion-2016-raises-over-800-000-to-build-hospital-in-syria | title = Passion 2016 Raises Over $800,000 To Build Hospital in Syria | last = Longs | first = Herb | website = ''TheChristianBeat.org'' | access-date = February 25, 2016 }}</ref> Passion 2017 saw the start of the Make History Together fundraising campaign, in which the organization partnered with Compassion International to sponsor children in poverty around the world. The students sponsored more than 7,000 children in total, including all the Compassion International children from El Salvador, Rwanda, Indonesia, and Tanzania, and another 900 children from Bolivia,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www1.cbn.com/cbnnews/2017/january/wow-millennials-lsquo-make-history-rsquo-at-passion-conference-by-sponsoring-7-000-kids-across-the-globe|title=Wow: Millennials ‘Make History’ at Passion Conference by Sponsoring 7,000 Kids Across the Globe|date=January 8, 2017|work=CBN News|access-date=November 19, 2018}}</ref> creating the largest surge of sponsorships in Compassion International's 65-year history.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.christianitytoday.com/news/2017/january/passion-conference-students-child-sponsorship-compassion.html|title=Passion Students Sponsor Every Compassion Child in Four Countries|work=News & Reporting|access-date=November 19, 2018}}</ref>

{{Use mdy dates|date=August 2016}} {{advert|date=August 2016}} {{Infobox convention | image = File:Slush_Black_Logo.png | name = Slush | status = Active | genre = Technology, Startups | venue = Messukeskus Helsinki, Expo and Convention Centre | location = Helsinki | country = Finland, Japan, China and Singapore | first = 2008 | last = | attendance = 20,000 (2017) | website = http://www.slush.org }}
'''Slush''' is a not-for-profit [[Startup company|startup]] and tech event. The main purpose of Slush is to facilitate meetings between the founders of start-ups and investors such as [[venture capitalist]]s, accomplished with events such as "match-making" and pitching competitions. Slush aims to change attitudes towards entrepreneurship by providing a platform for youths and student volunteers to co-organize and build a world-wide startup community. Held annually in [[Helsinki]], Finland, it has grown from a 300-person conference in 2008 into one of the leading global startup event of its kind in 2017. In 2017, Slush gathered 20,000 attendees,<ref>{{cite web|last1=Hixon|first1=Todd|title=A Report From The Hot And Cool Nordic Venture Scene|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/toddhixon/2015/11/14/a-report-from-the-hot-and-cool-nordic-venture-scene/#7ea65134a22a|website=Forbes|publisher=Forbes|accessdate=August 24, 2016}}</ref> with over 2,600 startups, 1,500 investors and 600 journalists coming in from over 130 countries to participate together in this global networking festival.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Haaramo|first1=Eeva|title=Slush 2015 breaks records as Finland's startup scene flourishes|url=http://www.computerweekly.com/news/4500257911/Slush-2015-breaks-records-as-Finlands-startup-scene-flourishes|website=Computer Weekly|publisher=Computer Weekly|accessdate=August 24, 2016}}</ref>
Since 2015, Slush also run events throughout the world in four major cities under Slush Tokyo, Slush Shanghai, and Slush Singapore.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.slush.org/about/what-is-slush/|website=Slush|accessdate=August 24, 2016|title=What Is Slush}}</ref>
== History == The founders of Slush were [[Peter Vesterbacka]], then working at [[Rovio Entertainment|Rovio]] with ''[[Angry Birds]]'', together with Timo Airisto, a lawyer.<ref>https://www.tivi.fi/Kaikki_uutiset/luulitko-etta-opiskelijat-perustivat-slushin-nain-15-000-hengen-startup-festivaali-sai-oikeasti-alkunsa-ja-nimensa-6603325</ref> In 2011, Miki Kuusi became the CEO, and together with Atte Hujanen and Jenni Kääriäinen organized the event at Kaapelitehdas, with 1500 attendees. The event was staffed mainly by student volunteers from [[Aaltoes]] (Aalto Entrepreneurship Society) of [[Aalto University]].<ref>https://nordic.businessinsider.com/dark-cold-and-miserable-how-slush-started-from-a-coffee-shop-chat-in-2011--and-became-europes-leading-tech-conference-in-four-years-2016-11/</ref>
=== 2017 === The 2017 event was organized between November 30–December 1, 2017 in [[Helsinki]], Finland.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.slush.org|title=Slush|website=Slush}}</ref> 20,000 attendees gathered together, including 2,600 startups, 1,500 investors, and 600 journalists from over 130 countries. Speakers included [[Al Gore]], former [[List of Vice Presidents of the United States|Vice President of the United States]], [[Tencent|Martin Lau]], President of Tencent, [[Ilkka Paananen]], co-founder & CEO of [[Supercell (video game company)|Supercell]] and [[Daniel Ek]], co-founder of [[Spotify]].
Hottest industry trends included [[analytics|data analytics]] and [[artificial intelligence]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ts.fi/uutiset/kotimaa/3748359/Analytiikka+ja+tekoaly+ovat+taman+vuoden+trendit+Slushissa|title=Analytiikka ja tekoäly ovat tämän vuoden trendit Slushissa|website=Turun Sanomat}}</ref> In 2017, more than 7000 "matchmaking" meetings had been set-up between founders and investors.<ref>https://yle.fi/uutiset/3-9949957</ref>
=== 2016 === Over 17,500 people from 130 countries, including 2,336 startups, 1,146 venture capitalists and investors, and 630 journalists gathered together at Slush 2016, on November 30–December 1. The speaker list had names like [[Chris Sacca]], Founder & Chairman at Lowercase Capital, [[Steve Jurvetson]], managing director at [[Draper Fisher Jurvetson]], [[Joel Spolsky]], CEO & Co-Founder at [[Stack Overflow]], [[Sebastian Siemiatkowski]], Founder & CEO of [[Klarna]] and [[Danae Ringelmann]], Co-founder of [[Indiegogo]], on it.<ref>{{cite web|title=On Stage 2016|url=http://www.slush.org/event/speakers/|website=On Stage 2016|accessdate=August 24, 2016}}</ref>
=== 2015 === In 2015, Slush was organized on November 11–12 in the [[Helsinki Exhibition and Convention Centre]]. Key speakers included [[Caterina Fake]], Co-founder of [[Flickr]] & [[Hunch (website)|Hunch]], [[Martti Ahtisaari]], [[Nobel Peace Prize]] laureate, [[Niklas Zennström]], Co-founder of [[Skype]] & [[Atomico]], and [[Ilkka Paananen]], Founder & CEO of [[Supercell]]. Slush was also awarded The Internationalisation Award of the President of the Republic in December 2015.<ref name="Press Release">{{cite web|title=The Internationalisation Award of the President of the Republic goes to Slush, Vahterus and Serres|url=http://www.exportfinland.fi/web/eng/2015-award-winners|website=Export Finland|publisher=Export Finland|accessdate=August 24, 2016}}</ref>
=== 2014 === In 2014, Slush moved from the Cable Factory to the Helsinki Exhibition and Convention Centre. The event, again, doubled its size from the previous year with 14,000 attendees. Out of the attendees, more than 700 were investors. The event was attended by journalists from 45 different countries. Speakers included [[Wang Yang (politician)|Wang Yang]], [[Vice Premier of the People's Republic of China|Vice Premier of China]], Martin Lorentzon, founder of [[Spotify]], [[Esa-Pekka Salonen]], Principal Conductor and Artistic Advisor of the [[Philharmonia Orchestra|Philharmonic Orchestra in London]], and [[Leland Melvin]], an American engineer and [[NASA]] [[astronaut]]. In 2014, [[Nokia]] also launched its [[Nokia N1]] 7.9" tablet at the main stage of Slush.<ref>{{cite web|title=Nokia Announces N1 Android Tablet|url=http://company.nokia.com/fi/news/press-releases/2014/11/18/nokia-announces-n1-android-tablet|website=Nokia|accessdate=August 24, 2016}}</ref>
=== 2013 === The 2013 event was attended by 7,000 people, including 1,200 startups and 120 VC firms, and it was featured in [[The New York Times]]<ref>{{cite news|last1=Scott|first1=Mark|title=Finns Pitch Frightful Weather as a Competitive Advantage|url=http://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/11/15/finns-pitch-frightful-weather-as-a-competitive-advantage/|accessdate=August 24, 2016|publisher=Bits, The New York Times}}</ref> and [[The Wall Street Journal]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Rossi|first1=Juhana|last2=Grundberg|first2=Sven|title=Finland's Prime Minister Looks to Startups|url=https://www.wsj.com/news/articles/SB10001424052702303289904579197803449054732|accessdate=August 24, 2016|publisher=The Wall Street Journal}}</ref> Speakers included [[Taizo Son]], Founder and CEO of [[Mistletoe, Inc.|Mistletoe]], [[Jian Wang (Alibaba Group)|Jian Wang]], Chairman of Technology Steering Committee of [[Alibaba Group]], [[Niklas Zennström]], founder of [[Skype]] and [[Atomico]], and Taavet Hinrikus, and Co-founder of [[Transferwise]].
=== 2008 === Founded by Helene Auramo, Kai Lemmetty, Ville Vesterinen and Peter Vesterbacka. First event was held in Korjaamo with two stages, one for business and one for technology.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Vesterinen|first1=Ville|title=SLUSH HELSINKI|url=http://arcticstartup.com/slush-helsinki/|accessdate=November 28, 2017|publisher=ArcticStartup}}</ref>

{{Infobox military conflict |partof=the wars of [[Italian Unification]] |conflict=Expedition of the Thousand |image=Image:Garibaldian volunteers..jpeg |caption=The British Legion in Southern Italy |date=1860–1861 |place= [[Southern Italy]] |casus= |territory= |result=Unification victory;
Collapse of the [[Kingdom of the Two Sicilies|Two Sicilies]] |combatant1=[[File:Flag of Italy.svg|23px]] [[Giuseppe Garibaldi]]
''[[Expedition of the Thousand#The Red Shirts|Red Shirts]]
[[:it:Esercito meridionale|Southern Army]]'' |combatant2={{flag|Two Sicilies}} |commander1=[[File:Flag of Italy (1861-1946).svg|23px]] [[File:Flag of Italy.svg|23px]]
[[Giuseppe Garibaldi]] |commander2={{flagicon|Two Sicilies}}
[[Francis II of the Two Sicilies|'''Francis II''']]
Giosuè Ritucci
Lukas von Mechel |strength1= |strength2= |casualties1= |casualties2= }} {{Campaignbox Expedition of the Thousand}} The '''British Legion''' was a voluntary military corps composed of Englishmen and Scots, who in 1860 made their mind up to join [[Giuseppe Garibaldi|Garibaldi]] during the [[Expedition of the thousand]] and fight for the [[unification of Italy]] together with the Italian Garibaldini against the Bourbon Army of [[The Kingdom of the Two Sicilies]]. Officially they were "Garibaldi Excursionists" to avoid any problems of diplomatic appearance and were recruited by major Styles, who appears in the engraving wearing his uniform and medal of the Crimean War.{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/?id=TYRUAAAAcAAJ&pg=PA371&dq=of+some+hal-dozen+shoulders+Harwich+by+the+morning+trains+from+london+and+embarked+thence#v=onepage&q=of+some+hal-dozen+shoulders+Harwich+by+the+morning+trains+from+london+and+embarked+thence&f=false|title=The Illustrated London News|date=26 February 1860|publisher=Leighton|via=Google Books}} The departure of "The British Legion" was financed by the "Garibaldi Special Fund Committee", one of the British organizations supporting the unification of Italy.{{cite web|url=http://discovery.nationalarchives.gov.uk/details/rd/31ec8715-63a5-4a29-98a4-bba99b336137|title=The Discovery Service|first=The National|last=Archives|website=discovery.nationalarchives.gov.uk}} ==Recruiting of the Legion== The advertisement that enlisted them ran as follows: "Excursion to Sicily and Naples. All persons (particularly Members of Volunteer Rifle Corps) desirous of visiting Southern Italy and of aiding by their presence and influence the 'Cause of Garibaldi and Italy', may learn how to proceed by applying to the Garibaldi Committee at the offices, No. 8 Salisbury Street, London." Holyoake, i. 245 ==The volunteers== The volunteers of the British Legion are described in a news item of ''The Illustrated London News'' of Oct. 20, 1860 regarding the departure from Harwich of 800600 according to G.M. Trevelyan - page 260 Englishmen and Scotchmen, who put their sword at the disposal of Garibaldi. ''The Illustrated London News'' remarks that, including volunteers already with Garibaldi, the total amount is a considerable more than 1,000 volunteers in the Garibaldian Army, often from middle-class or well-paid jobs, who left their country attracted by adventure and love of freedom, to fight for the liberty of a foreign country. Before their departure from England other British volunteers were already at the side of Garibaldi in the South of Italy, such as Hugh Forbes, who was with Garibaldi in 1849, taking part in the defence of the Roman Republic against the French troops supporting the papacy,Garibaldi's defence of the Roman Republic 1848-1849 – [[George Macaulay Trevelyan]] - Longmans - 1919 - appendix N, pages 349-350 John Whitehead Peard, the "double" of Garibaldi or the charismatic Colonel John Dunne and his "English battalion" whose soldiers were all Sicilians and called Dunne "Milordo|, Dunne was wounded in Capua,Garibaldi and the making of Italy, George Macaulay Trevelyan – page 64, 241 Percy Wyndam and several others. John Whitehead Peard took the lead of the British Legion after its landing in Naples. After having sailed from Great Britain by the ships Melazzo and Emperor, the British Legion landed in Naples on 15 October 1860 and took part in a fight, under the command of [[John Whitehead Peard]] in Sant'Angelo up to the wall of [[Capua]], where two volunteers were killed and eight wounded.Garibaldi and the making of Italy, George Macaulay Trevelyan, pages 259-260 Even if a half of the volunteers were enthusiastic and behaved properly, there were some roughs, principally from Glasgow and London who lacked discipline, so the Legion acquired a name for disorder similar to that which the Pope’s Irish had acquired in Rome. The Italians said "indulgently", "these men are not accustomed to a country where wine is cheap." ==The Legion on the battlefield == The Legion had a short war experience, after having advanced northwards with Garibaldi and a few regiments of Italians, on the morning of October 26, while they were in Vajrano, an Englishman from the Garibaldian outposts heard the war-cry ''"Viva il re !"'', "Long live the king!", usually shouted by the soldiers of the Bourbon Army, but it was the same war-cry from the Army of King Victor Emmnuel II, the future king of Italy, coming from the north. The red-shirts were replaced by the king’s Army in the final siege of the fortress in Gaeta, where the Bourbon Army surrendered in February 1861. ==References== {{Reflist}} == Sources == {{commons category|Spedizione dei Mille}} *{{cite book|first=George Macaulay |last=Trevelyan|title=Garibaldi and the making of Italy|year=1911}} * Janet Fyfe, ''Scottish volunteers with Garibaldi'', Scottish Historical Review Trust, Edimburgh, 1978. * Marcella Pellegrino Sutcliffe, ''British Red Shirts: A History of the Garibaldi Volunteers (1860)'', University of Cambridge, Chapter 12 of ''Transnational Soldiers: Foreign Military Enlistment in the Modern Era'' by di N. Arielli,B. {{Infobox film | name = The Charge of the Light Brigade | image = Thechargeofthelightbrigade1936.jpg | border = yes | alt = | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[Michael Curtiz]] | producer = {{Plainlist| uncredited }} | screenplay = {{Plainlist| * Michel Jacoby * and [[Rowland Leigh]] }} | based on = {{based on|original story|Michel Jacoby}} | starring = {{Plainlist| * [[Errol Flynn]] * [[Olivia de Havilland]] }} | music = [[Max Steiner]] | cinematography = [[Sol Polito]] [[A.S.C.]] | editing = [[George Amy]] | studio = [[Warner Bros.|Warner Bros. Pictures]] | distributor = Warner Bros. Pictures | released = {{Film date|1936|10|20|USA}} | runtime = 115 minutes | country = United States | language = English | budget = $1,330,000[https://www.researchgate.net/publication/239595348_Hollywood's_foreign_earnings_during_the_1930s John Sedgwick, Mike Pokorny, "Hollywood’s foreign earnings during the 1930s", 83 TRAC 1 (1) pp. 83–97 Intellect Limited 2010 p92] or $1,076,000Warner Bros financial information in The William Shaefer Ledger. See Appendix 1, Historical Journal of Film, Radio and Television, (1995) 15:sup1, 1-31 p 16 DOI: 10.1080/01439689508604551 | gross = $2,736,000 }} '''''The Charge of the Light Brigade''''' is a 1936 American [[historical period drama|historical]] [[adventure film]] made by [[Warner Bros.]]''[[Variety Film Reviews|Variety]]'' film review; November 4, 1936, page 18.''[[Harrison's Reports and Film Reviews|Harrison's Reports]]'' film review; November 7, 1936, page 178. It was directed by [[Michael Curtiz]] and produced by [[Samuel Bischoff]], with [[Hal B. Wallis]] as executive producer, from a [[screenplay]] by Michael Jacoby and [[Rowland Leigh]], from a story by Michael Jacoby based on the poem ''[[The Charge of the Light Brigade (poem)|The Charge of the Light Brigade]]'' by [[Alfred, Lord Tennyson]]. The music score was by [[Max Steiner]]; his first for Warners and the cinematography by [[Sol Polito]]. Scenes were shot at the following California locations: [[Lone Pine, California|Lone Pine]], [[Sherwood Lake, California|Sherwood Lake]], Lasky Mesa, Chatsworth and [[Sonora, California|Sonora]]. The [[Sierra Nevada (U.S.)|Sierra Nevada]] mountains were used for the [[Khyber Pass]] scenes.http://www.tcm.com/tcmdb/title/2098/The-Charge-of-the-Light-Brigade/notes.html The film starred [[Errol Flynn]] and [[Olivia de Havilland]]. The story is very loosely based on the famous [[Charge of the Light Brigade]] that took place during the [[Crimean War]] (1853–56). Additionally, the story line includes an event similar to the [[Siege of Cawnpore]] during the [[Indian Rebellion of 1857]]. This was the second of eight films in which Errol Flynn and Olivia de Havilland starred together. A latter film was made in 1968, under the same name, ''[[The Charge of the Light Brigade (1968 film)|The Charge of the Light Brigade]]'' and starred [[Trevor Howard]] and [[Vanessa Redgrave]]. == Plot == In 1854, Major Geoffrey Vickers ([[Errol Flynn]]) and his brother, Captain Perry Vickers ([[Patric Knowles]]), are stationed in [[British Raj|India]], with the 27th Lancers of the [[British Army]]. It is during the period of [[Company rule in India|East India Company dominance]] over the [[Indian subcontinent]]. Perry has secretly betrayed Geoffrey by stealing the love of his fiancee Elsa ([[Olivia de Havilland]]). During an official visit to local tributary rajah, Surat Khan ([[C. Henry Gordon]]), Geoffrey saves the rajah's life while hunting, for which the rajah promises eternal gratitude. Later, Maj. Vickers is stationed at the British garrison of (fictional) Chukoti, along with British military families, within the part the [[North-Western Frontier]] controlled by Surat Khan. A British miscalculation leads to premature withdrawal of troops to (fictional) Lohora, unnecessarily exposing Chukoti. Faced with an overwhelming siege, the British commander, Col. Campbell ([[Donald Crisp]]), surrenders Chukoti to Surat Khan, who then massacres the inhabitants, including British families. Surat Khan allies his forces with [[Imperial Russia]], whom the British are fighting in the Crimean War, but spares Maj. Vickers and Elsa as they flee the slaughter. This repays his debt to Geoffrey. The [[love triangle]] and the quest for [[Revenge|vengeance]] resolve at the [[Battle of Balaclava]]. Aware that Surat Khan is inspecting Russian positions opposite the 27th Lancers, Maj. Vickers secretly replaces written orders by Sir Charles Macefield ([[Henry Stephenson]]) to the commander of the [[Light cavalry|Light Brigade]], Sir Benjamin Warrenton ([[Nigel Bruce]]), to withdraw from the Balaclava Heights. Vickers instead orders the famous suicidal attack so the lancers can avenge the Chukoti massacre. Before the charge, Maj. Vickers reminds troops of the Chukoti Massacre and directs their anger: "Our objective is Surit Khan!" Although the 27th Lancers lose nearly all their 600 strength, they successfully breach Russian artillery positions. There, Vickers finds and kills Surat Khan, at the cost of his own life. Later, it emerges that Maj. Vickers wrote to Sir Charles Macefield explaining his actions, a note which he forced his brother Perry to deliver, under threat of [[Court-martial|court martial]], so sparing his brother almost certain death. After receiving Maj. Vickers' explanation of why the charge happened, Macefield takes responsibility and burns the note to protect Vickers' good name. ==Cast== * [[Errol Flynn]] as Major Geoffrey Vickers * [[Olivia de Havilland]] as Elsa Campbell * [[Patric Knowles]] as Captain Perry Vickers * [[Henry Stephenson]] as Sir Charles Macefield * [[Nigel Bruce]] as Sir Benjamin Warrenton * [[Donald Crisp]] as Colonel Campbell * [[David Niven]] as Captain Randall * [[C. Henry Gordon]] as Surat Khan * G. P. Huntley, Jr. as Major Jowett * [[Robert Barrat]] as Count Igor Volonoff * [[Spring Byington]] as Lady Octavia Warrenton * [[E. E. Clive]] as Sir Humphrey Harcourt * [[J. Carrol Naish]] as Subahdar-Major Puran Singh * Walter Holbrook as Cornet Barclay * Princess Baigum as Prema's Mother * Charles Sedgwick as Cornet Pearson * [[Scotty Beckett]] as Prema Singh * [[George Regas]] as Wazir * Helen Sanborn as Mrs. Jowett * [[Holmes Herbert]] as Gen. O'Neill (uncredited) {{div col end}} ==Production== ===Development=== The charge had been portrayed in a British movie, ''The Jaws of Death'', in 1930. Warner Bros were inspired to make the film after ''[[The Lives of a Bengal Lancer (film)|Lives of a Bengal Lancer]]'' (1935) had been released to great popularity, ushering in a series of [[British Empire]] adventure tales. Michel Jacoby had developed a story based on the famous charge but, although Warners bought Jacoby's script, the final script was closer to ''Lives of a Bengal Lancer''.Tony Thomas, Rudy Behlmer * Clifford McCarty, ''The Films of Errol Flynn'', Citadel Press, 1969 p 45-50 An original working title was ''The Charge of the 600''.Tennyson 's Celebrated "Charge of the Light Brigade " Inspiration for New Film: Miss Colbert Will Be Star of 'Frenchy' Moroni Olsen Given Musketeer Role; Jones to Sing Schallert, Edwin. Los Angeles Times (1923-Current File) [Los Angeles, Calif] 13 June 1935: 13. Warners wanted an all-British cast. [[Errol Flynn]] (Australian, but often considered Irish) had made such a strong impression in ''[[Captain Blood (1935 film)|Captain Blood]]'' he was removed from supporting [[Fredric March]] in ''[[Anthony Adverse]]'' to play the lead in ''Charge of the Light Brigade''.Chaplin's Big Business: Goldwyn's Leading Lady: A New Romantic Hero Bain, Greville. The Times of India (1861-current) [New Delhi, India] 07 Mar 1936: 9. [[Ian Hunter (actor)|Ian Hunter]] was connected to the film early on.Irvin S Cobb, Famous Humorist, Signs to Star at Twentieth Century-Fox: Zanuck Picks Story for Writer-Player Francine Larrimore Arriving October 20 to Do Picture Work for M.-G.-M.; Featured Roles Awarded Melvyn Douglas Schallert, Edwin. Los Angeles Times (1923-Current File) [Los Angeles, Calif] 18 Sep 1935: 9. [[Anita Louise]] was announced as the female lead.SCREEN NOTES New York Times (1923-Current file) [New York, N.Y] 20 Mar 1936: 28. [[Patric Knowles]] had just joined Warner Bros at the recommendation of [[Irving Asher]] in London, the same man who recommended Errol Flynn. He was given the crucial support part of Flynn's brother.Irvin Cobb, Film Future Secure, to Star in "Gentleman From Mississippi": Writer's Thespianic Adventure Proceeds Claude Rains and Charles Boyer Both Will Have Fling at Napoleon Interpretation; Choir Singer in "Stagestruck" Schallert, Edwin. Los Angeles Times (1923-Current File) [Los Angeles, Calif] 09 Mar 1936: 15. The movie gave an early important role for David Niven.Bette Davis, Academy Winner, Will Break Up Film Duties With Vacation: Star Going to Palm Springs, Honolulu Randolph Scott Will Portray Scout Hawkeye in "Last of Mohicans;" Sol Lesser Plans Films for Twentieth-Century Release Schallert, Edwin. Los Angeles Times (1923-Current File) [Los Angeles, Calif] 07 Mar 1936: 5. [[Edward G. Robinson]] tested for the role of the lead villain Surat Khan. [[Basil Rathbone]] was also considered before C Henry Gordon was cast.Franchot Tone Selected to Appear Opposite Jean Harlow in "Suzy" Film: George Fitzmaurice Will Direct Feature Harriet Hilliard's Next Picture Will Be "Make a Wish;" Capra Seeking Tibetans; Beverly Roberts Wins Leading Part Schallert, Edwin. Los Angeles Times (1923-Current File) [Los Angeles, Calif] 20 Mar 1936: 15. ===Shooting=== Shooting started April 1936.Jungle Scene Gives Actors Extra Thrill Shaffer, George. Chicago Daily Tribune (1923-1963) [Chicago, Ill] 15 Apr 1936: 22. During filming on location at Lone Pine California the unit helped put out a fire which started at a restaurant across the road from where the actors were staying.Movie Crew Aids Firemen New York Times (1923-Current file) [New York, N.Y] 02 Apr 1936: 29. There was some shooting done in Mexico where there were fewer restrictions on hurting animals.NEWS OF THE SCREEN: Forward the Light Brigade, to Mexico -- More Costumes for Hepburn -- Trivial Matters. New York Times (1923-Current file) [New York, N.Y] 15 June 1936: 24. ===The Charge sequence=== The film comes to a climax at the [[Battle of Balaclava]], subject of [[Lord Tennyson]]'s poem ''[[The Charge of the Light Brigade (poem)|The Charge of the Light Brigade]]''. The lancers charge into the valley and brave the Russian cannons, and many are killed. Text from Tennyson's poem is superimposed on the screen, coupled with [[Max Steiner]]'s musical score. Director [[Michael Curtiz]], who did not have an excellent command of English, shouted "Bring on the empty horses", meaning "riderless horses". David Niven used this as the title of his book about the [[Golden Age of Hollywood]]. The battlefield set was lined with [[tripwire]]s to trip the cavalry horses. For the filming of the climactic charge, 125 horses were tripped; of those, 25 were killed or had to be put down afterward. Errol Flynn, an accomplished horseman, was outraged by the animal cruelty and by director Michael Curtiz's seeming indifference and attacked Curtiz. They were pulled apart before any serious damage was done. The charge sequence forced the [[U.S. Congress]] to ensure the safety of animals in motion pictures; the [[ASPCA]] followed suit and banned tripwires from films. Unlike Flynn's other blockbuster films, because of the number of horses killed, it was never re-released by Warner Brothers, and so wouldn't be seen again until 1956, when Warner Brothers sold the rights to it and other pre-1950 films to [[Associated Artists Productions]] and it subsequently premiered on television. ==Stylized as a cenotaph in opening credits== {{col-begin}} {{col-2}} "QUIS SUPERABIT
WHO SHALL EXCEL THEM
Dedication
To the officers and men
Of the Light Brigade who
Died victorious in a gallant
Charge at Balaklava for
Queen and Country
A.D. 1856" {{col-2}} "The world is indebted to Alfred,
Lord Tennyson, Poet Laureate to
Her Majesty, Queen Victoria of
Great Britain, for perpetuating
in an epic poem one of the most
distinguished events in history
conspicuous for sheer valor…" {{col-end}} ==Disclaimer at the end of opening credits== "This production has its basis in history.
The historical basis, however, has been
fictionized for the purposes of this picture
and the names of many characters, many
characters themselves, the story, incidents
and institutions, are fictitious. With the
exception of known historical characters,
whose actual names are herein used, no
identification with actual persons, living
or dead, is intended or should be inferred." ==Reception== ===Box Office=== The film was a massive hit in Japan.https://archive.org/stream/variety129-1938-01#page/n27/mode/1up/search/gross According to Warner Bros' accounts, the film was the studio's most expensive and most popular film of 1936, earning $1,176,000 domestically and $1,560,000 foreign. ==Awards== [[Jack Sullivan (film director)|Jack Sullivan]] won the [[Academy Award for Best Assistant Director]] for his work on the film, and the film was also nominated for the [[Academy Award for Sound]] ([[Nathan Levinson]]) and the [[Academy Award for Original Music Score]].{{cite web|url=http://www.oscars.org/oscars/ceremonies/1937 |title=The 9th Academy Awards (1937) Nominees and Winners |accessdate=2011-08-08|work=oscars.org}} ==See also== * [[List of American films of 1936]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== {{commons category|The Charge of the Light Brigade (1936 film)}} * {{IMDb title}} * {{TCMDb title}} * {{AllMovie title}} * {{AFI film}} * {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20030405070346/http://www.crimeantexts.org.uk/topics/movie36.html |date=April 5, 2003 |title=A historical assessment from CrimeanTexts.org.uk }} {{Michael Curtiz}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Charge of the Light Brigade (1936 film), The}} [[Category:1936 films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:American black-and-white films]] [[Category:British Empire war films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Crimean War films]] [[Category:Films scored by Max Steiner]] [[Category:Films based on poems]] [[Category:Films based on works by Alfred Tennyson]] [[Category:Films directed by Michael Curtiz]] [[Category:Films set in the British Raj]] [[Category:Films set in 1854]] [[Category:War films based on actual events]] [[Category:Warner Bros. films]] [[Category:Animal cruelty incidents]] [[Category:1930s war films]] [[Category:Films produced by Samuel Bischoff]] [[Category:Films produced by Hal B. '''The Possum Drop''' is any one of several [[New Year's Day]] celebrations in which a [[Virginia opossum|possum]] is lowered from height at midnight. In contrast to other [[List of objects dropped on New Year's Eve|events of its kind]], which typically involve replicas, a "possum drop" uses a live animal as its prop.
==Brasstown Drop== In [[Brasstown, North Carolina (Unincorporated Community)|Brasstown, North Carolina]] an annual event at Clay's Corner [[convenience store]] is organized by proprietors Clay and Judy Logan.<ref>Clay's Corner - Clay & Judy Logan Proprietors http://www.clayscorner.com</ref> At midnight on [[New Year's Eve]], instead of dropping an inanimate object, a plexiglass pyramid containing a live opossum was lowered from the roof of the store.<ref>New Year's Eve Lowering of the Opossum http://www.clayscorner.com/new-years-eve.shtml</ref> The animal is lowered to prevent the occurrence of injury. The opossum is not actually "dropped;" [[List of objects dropped on New Year's Eve|events of its kind]], it is lowered in the same manner as a [[time ball]].
The festivities include a contest with local men dressed as women to compete for the title "Miss Possum [[Drag queen|Queen]]" as well as [[bluegrass music]], snacks and beverages, and [[souvenir]] merchandise.<ref>{{cite web|work=The New York Times|title=Keep Your Ball. We’ve Got the Possum.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2003/12/31/national/31POSS.html|author=JEFFREY GETTLEMAN|date=December 31, 2003}}</ref><ref name=autogenerated1>Mountain Manager & Associates {{cite web |url=http://www.mountainmanager.net/localinterest.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-04-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110723211948/http://www.mountainmanager.net/localinterest.htm |archivedate=2011-07-23 |df= }}</ref>
==Tallapoosa Drop== In [[Tallapoosa, Georgia]] Danny Welch organizes the annual event.<ref>The Possum Drop http://www.thepossumdrop.com/</ref><ref>WSBTV.com - Entertainment - Story: Georgia Town Celebrates New Years With Possum Drop http://www.wsbtv.com/entertainment/22103037/detail.html</ref> The Possum Drop festivities include food vendors, T-shirts and souvenirs, live music, and fireworks after midnight. The Master of Ceremonies for the 2018 celebration is George Franco with Fox 5 News in Atlanta. Attendance in recent years has been in excess of 7000. This event differs from the one in Brasstown, NC due to the usage of a taxidermied possum rather than a live one.
Spencer the famous possum is suspended in a wire ball wrapped with Christmas lights and is kept at ground level most of the night to allow spectators to see and have pictures taken with him. At about 11:30 PM he is raised to his full height to the top of the Cain Law Firm Building and at midnight amidst great fanfare and cheers is slowly lowered to the ground to signify the start of the new year. A living animal is not lowered: Spencer was a real opossum found dead in the wild and was stuffed by local [[Taxidermy|taxidermist]] Bud Jones. Spencer's name is a tribute to Ralph L. Spencer.<ref name=autogenerated2>RoadsideGeorgia.com http://roadsidegeorgia.com/city/tallapoosa.html</ref>
The event has grown over the last five years and attracts visitors from across the country who travel to Tallapoosa, Ga to celebrate New Year's Eve. The event has caught the attention of local and national media. The Learning Channel(TLC) chose The Possum Drop in Tallapoosa, Ga. as the location to film the New Years Special for their hit series "[[Here Comes Honey Boo Boo#Criticism|Here comes Honey Boo Boo]]" which will air in February or March 2014
==Opposition== Possum drops have been subject to criticism and protest from [[PETA]], an organization that considers the drop a form of [[animal cruelty]].<ref name=autogenerated1 /><ref name=nytimes>A New Year's Tradition Lives, But the 4-Legged Star Doesn't. https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9802E7DF1631F931A35752C0A9629C8B63</ref> PETA successfully sued to stop the 2013 Brasstown possum drop, under the premise that the state wildlife commission did not have the authority to issue the permits for such an event.<ref>{{cite web|author=Shaffer, Josh|date=November 13, 2012|url=http://www.newsobserver.com/2012/11/13/2481006/opossum-drop-halted-in-brasstown.html|title=NC judge halts Brasstown's Opossum Drop|work=Raleigh News-Observer|accessdate=November 14, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121115214515/http://www.newsobserver.com/2012/11/13/2481006/opossum-drop-halted-in-brasstown.html|archivedate=November 15, 2012|df=}}</ref> North Carolina General Statue 113-274-(c)-(1c) appears to authorize the state wildlife commission to issue such permits.<ref>[http://www.ncleg.net/EnactedLegislation/Statutes/HTML/BySection/Chapter_113/GS_113-274.html N.C.G.S 113-274]</ref> {{Quote box |quote = (c) The Wildlife Resources Commission may issue the following permits:
(1b) Captivity Permit. - Authorizes the possession of live wildlife that may lawfully be permitted to be retained alive, in accordance with governing rules of the Wildlife Resources Commission. This permit may not substitute for any required collection license or captivity license, but may be temporarily issued for possession of wild animals or wild birds pending action on a captivity license or following its denial or termination. If this permit is issued for fish to be held indefinitely, the Wildlife Resources Commission may provide for periodic renewals of the permit, at least once each three years, to insure a review of the circumstances and conditions under which fish are kept. Wild animals and wild birds kept temporarily in captivity under this permit must be humanely treated and in accordance with any stipulations in the permit, but the standards of caging and care applicable to species kept under the captivity license do not apply unless specified in the permit. Any substantial deviation from reasonable requirements imposed by rule or administratively under the authority of this section renders the possession of the wildlife unlawful.
}}
In spite of this, the organizers used a dead opossum instead, after deciding they could not afford legal expenses that could result from defying PETA's request as they had originally planned to do.<ref name=nytimes/> PETA did not object to using an already dead animal.<ref name=observer122914>Jarvis, Craig (December 29, 2014). [http://www.charlotteobserver.com/2014/12/29/5412732/possum-drop-organizer-wont-use.html#.VKG48F4AKA ‘Possum Drop’ organizer won’t use live opossum this year]. ''Charlotte Observer''. Retrieved December 31, 2014.</ref> The North Carolina legislature passed a law in 2013 to expressly allow the commission to issue such permits, and the Brasstown event resumed in 2014 Thousands local residents and from all over the US signed petitions to stop this event using a live opossum.<ref name=wtvr-possumdrop>{{cite web|title=Controversial possum drop prevails in NC|url=http://wtvr.com/2014/01/01/possum-drop-brasstown/|work=WTVR|publisher=[[Tribune Broadcasting]]|accessdate=2 January 2014}}</ref>
Brasstown received more national attention for the 2015 New Year Possum Drop when PETA again filed a motion to prevent Clay Logan from obtaining a capture permit; Logan had already decided, due to time concerns, not to obtain a state permit for that year's drop.<ref name=observer122914/>
Many residents of the city of Tallapoosa consider the event and its production quality to be "[[redneck]]" and are against using the possum moniker to promote "Possum Snout", a nickname considered demeaning to the history of Tallapoosa (which means "Golden Water" or "Gold In Water" in the language of the [[Indigenous_peoples_of_the_Americas|Native American]] Muscogee).[http://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=The_Possum_Drop&oldid=588388731#cite_note-10 10][http://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=The_Possum_Drop&oldid=588388731#cite_note-autogenerated2-9 9][http://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=The_Possum_Drop&oldid=588388731#cite_note-11 11][http://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=The_Possum_Drop&oldid=588388731#cite_note-12 12]
==External links== *[http://www.clayscorner.com/new-years-eve.shtml Clay Corner's site] *[http://www.peta.org/b/thepetafiles/archive/2013/10/30/peta-files-lawsuit-to-stop-opossum-drop.aspx PETA Files Lawsuit to Stop Opossum Drop]
==References== {{reflist}} {{New Year}}
